M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 215, § 6)

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 215, § 6)

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 215, § 6)

Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jennifer Smith (“Mother”), brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and c. 209C, § 20, seeking to modify the existing custody and parenting time judgment entered by this Court on May 15, 2017, regarding the parties’ minor child, Emma Smith (born [DOB intentionally omitted for privacy]).

c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jennifer Smith (“Mother”), brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and c. 209C, § 20, seeking to modify the existing custody and parenting time judgment entered by this Court on May 15, 2017, regarding the parties’ minor child, Emma Smith (born [DOB intentionally omitted for privacy]).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may revise or alter a custody or parenting plan judgment upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters concerning the custody, care, and support of the minor child under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: See Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015) (court must find both a material change and that modification serves the child’s best interests).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: This opinion is a removal and child support modification case; it does not state or apply a general rule that a court must find both a material change in circumstances and that modification serves the child’s best interests. For the removal claim, it articulates and applies the Yannas two-prong "real advantage" and best-interests test, not a material-change requirement. For child support, it notes the statutory standard for modifying support orders but does not tie that to a best-interests analysis as part of a dual requirement in the way the proposition describes.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt:
“In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’ … Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’…

…G. L. c. 208, § 28…provides that a child support order shall be modified ‘if there is an inconsistency between the amount of the existing order and the amount that would result from application of the child support guidelines.’”}

Kirby v. Kirby, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 678 (2.raw_text: Kirby v. Kirby, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 678 (2017)
Kirby v. Kirby, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 678 (2.proposition: The standard for modification is well established: a change in circumstances that affects the child’s welfare and makes the existing order inconsistent with her current best interests.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The standard for modification is well established: a change in circumstances that affects the child’s welfare and makes the existing order inconsistent with her current best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion is an initial custody determination and remand focused on the requirement of explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not discuss or set out the standard for modification of an existing custody order based on a change in circumstances or inconsistency with the child’s current best interests. The claimed modification standard therefore is not addressed or established in this case.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The “best interests of the child” are the paramount concern of the Court in all custody determinations.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in deciding custody, the court’s overriding concern must be promotion of the children’s best interests and general welfare, and it cites prior cases characterizing what is best for the children’s welfare as the ‘sole question.’ The court applies that standard in affirming the custody award, making clear that the best interests of the child control the custody determination. This directly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in all custody determinations.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) (‘sole question’ is what is best for children’s welfare).”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: The “best interests of the child” are the paramount concern of the Court in all custody determinations.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss that custody and care-and-protection dispositions must consider the children’s best interests, but it does not state that the best interests standard is the paramount concern in *all* custody determinations. Instead, it emphasizes the dual tests of parental fitness and best interests, noting they are not mutually exclusive but different emphases on the same factors. The court’s focus here is on parental unfitness plus a best-interests analysis of competing placements, not a universal, paramount best-interests rule for every custody case.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’ … In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests and issued more than a broad dispositional order committing them to the permanent custody of the department.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court evaluates not only the parents’ respective circumstances but also the developmental and emotional needs of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames the removal inquiry in terms of the children’s “best interests,” explicitly defined as grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child. In applying that standard, the opinion discusses the older child’s ADHD, learning and socialization issues, the effects of a school change, disruption to his “developmental process,” and emotional harm from parental conflict, alongside the parents’ living situations and custody arrangements. This shows the court evaluates both parental circumstances and the child’s developmental and emotional needs.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The judge concluded that, in light of the disruptions to his developmental process that would be occasioned by the challenges of a new home, school, and sibling, and reduction in the time spent with the father, the move to New Hampshire would be ‘detrimental’ to the older child’s socialization and education.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court evaluates not only the parents’ respective circumstances but also the developmental and emotional needs of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, explicitly weighing not only the parents’ respective work schedules, caregiving patterns, and capacities but also the child’s needs for stability, continuity, medical attention, education, and relationship with each parent. The court emphasizes considering how arrangements affect Kali’s day-to-day life, her need for stability, and her relationships, which are core developmental and emotional needs. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the court evaluates both parental circumstances and the child’s developmental and emotional needs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including… that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues…; that the father works long hours…; that the mother has more flexible hours and is able to spend more time with Kali…; [and] that it is important that Kali be able to spend as much time as possible with her father… to continue to foster their close and positive relationship.”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: A parent’s post-judgment improvements in stability, housing, and ability to provide consistent care can constitute a material change supporting modification.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: This is an alimony modification case, not a custody or parenting case, and it does not address post‑judgment changes in a parent’s stability, housing, or ability to provide consistent care as grounds for modification. The court’s discussion of “material change of circumstances” is framed entirely in terms of income, retirement, assets, and financial need between former spouses. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition about parental improvements supporting a modification.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A parent’s post-judgment improvements in stability, housing, and ability to provide consistent care can constitute a material change supporting modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances sufficient to justify modifying custody from the mother to the father. The court holds there was no such change and, in fact, rejects the asserted changes (including work schedule, temporary change in residence, etc.) as insufficient to support modification. It does not discuss or endorse a parent’s post-judgment improvements in stability, housing, or caregiving as constituting a material change; instead it concludes there was nothing since the divorce that warranted a change in custody.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.proposition: The Court also gives weight to a child’s expressed preferences, especially as the child matures.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely focused on parental unfitness, standards of proof, and the need for specific findings in care-and-protection proceedings. It does not discuss the child’s wishes, maturity, or the role of a child’s expressed preferences in custody determinations. There is no language suggesting that the court gave any weight to, or even considered, a child’s stated preferences, so it cannot be cited for that proposition.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: Because the interest of the child is thought to be best served in the stable, continuous environment of his own family... State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Court also gives weight to a child’s expressed preferences, especially as the child matures.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is lengthy and detailed on best-interests analysis, sibling relationships, bonding, expert testimony, and competing adoption plans, but it does not discuss or give weight to any expressed preferences of the child. Hugo is very young and the court focuses on expert assessments and attachments, not on his stated wishes or a maturing child’s autonomy. Thus, the case does not establish or affirm a principle about considering an older child’s expressed custodial or adoption preferences.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: We have been careful to observe that a sibling relationship is but one factor, albeit an important one, that a judge should consider in custody cases. See Care & Protection of Three Minors, supra (even where siblings spent time together and expressed desire to live together, sibling relationship is not dispositive). Siblings who are separated from their biological parents no doubt play an important role in each others’ lives. See id. at 714-715.

Miller v. Miller, 448 Mass. 320 (2007).proposition: The child’s therapeutic evidence and the child’s expressed desire for more time with a parent are legitimate factors supporting modification.
Miller v. Miller, 448 Mass. 320 (2007).support_reasoning: This opinion is about subject matter and personal jurisdiction in a divorce case, focusing on domicile, the locus of the irretrievable breakdown, and the Massachusetts long-arm statute. It does not address standards for modifying custody or parenting time, and it contains no discussion of therapeutic evidence or a child’s stated preference regarding time with a parent as factors in modification. Therefore it does not support the claimed proposition.
Miller v. Miller, 448 Mass. 320 (2007).relevant_excerpt: We transferred this case from the Appeals Court to *321 consider a reported question from a judge in the Probate and Family Court whether her interlocutory ruling that the court had personal jurisdiction over the defendant husband pursuant to G. L. c. 223A, § 3 (g), was proper. … We also conclude that the court has subject matter jurisdiction over the case. Accordingly, we remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The child’s therapeutic evidence and the child’s expressed desire for more time with a parent are legitimate factors supporting modification.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The concurring opinion excerpt deals with relocation, statutory interpretation under the paternity statute, and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss standards for later modification of custody or visitation, nor does it address the evidentiary role of a child’s therapeutic evidence or the child’s expressed wishes. Nothing in the provided text suggests that the child’s therapy-related evidence or desire for more time with a parent is identified as a legitimate factor supporting modification.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...').
